metadata.synopsis: Beautiful bookseller Virginia (Jenny Wright) fosters a growing interest in the works of reclusive novelist Malcolm Brand (Randall William Cook). After much fruitless searching, Virginia finally receives a package containing Brand's recent book, "I, Madman," about a deranged doctor spurned by a beautiful woman. But, as Virginia devours Brand's latest offering, she begins to have chilling visions of characters from the book -- and the line between fiction and reality grows terrifyingly thin.

reviews: A genuinely moody film, and an exercise in imagination enhanced by the paperback nostalgia of a faded era of strange, adult entertainment
Nifty and draggy in equal measure, this finally goes off the rails but has a fun time getting there.
A passable low-budget horror flick with a winning performance by Jenny Wright (Near Dark).
This quirky and oddly nightmarish film doesn't always make sense but certainly gets points for trying.
Climaxes in thrillers have gotten pretty standard recently, involving chases and shootouts and a lot of blood. I, Madman has some surprises.
